questions.text: What proportion of healthcare waste is hazardous waste?
questions.solution:
15% of health care waste is hazardous waste. It may be infectious, toxic, or radioactive in nature. The remaining 85% is general, non-hazardous waste.

Bio-medical waste means any waste that is generated during:

  • Diagnosis, treatment, or immunization of human beings or animals 
  • Research activities pertaining thereto
  • Production or testing of biologicals

Bio-medical waste is handled as per the Bio-medical Waste Management Rules, 2016. However, these rules do not apply to the following:

  • Radioactive wastes
  • Hazardous chemicals
  • Solid wastes
  • Lead-acid batteries
  • Hazardous wastes
  • e-Waste
  • Hazardous microorganisms

questions.text: Cytotoxic and expired drugs are disposed by:
questions.solution:
Cytotoxic and expired drugs are collected in a yellow bag and then disposed of by incineration. 

Expired cytotoxic drugs are to be returned to the manufacturer and subjected to incineration, encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis. Other discarded medicines can be disposed by incineration.

questions.text: Which of the following category of wastes are treated by autoclaving and microwaving?
questions.solution:
The final treatment of catheters, urine bags, and gloves is done by autoclaving and microwaving.

They belong to recyclable contaminated waste and are disposed of in a red bag.

Option A: Human anatomical waste is disposed of by incineration.

Option C: Cytotoxic and expired/discarded medicine is disposed of by incineration/plasma pyrolysis/disposal in a secured landfill.

Option D: Microbiological waste such as culture plates and slides are pre-treated with nonchlorinated chemicals and later disposed of by incineration.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about yellow waste disposal bags?
  1. They are made from non-chlorinated plastic material
  2. Chemical liquid wastes are collected in it
  3. Metallic body implants are discarded in it
  4. Polyvinyl chloride gloves are discarded in it and sent for incineration
  5. Animal anatomical waste is collected in it and sent for chemical treatment
questions.solution:
Yellow waste disposal bags are made from non-chlorinated plastic material and chemical liquid wastes are collected in them.

Chlorinated items, glass, metal, and rubber are not sent for incineration as incinerating them would produce carcinogenic gases.

The right disposal methods of the other options are:

  • Animal anatomical waste - Collected in yellow bags and later sent for incineration. 
  • Metallic body implants - Collected in cardboard boxes with blue coloured marking and sent for recycling following autoclaving.
  • PVC gloves - Collected in red bags and sent for autoclaving followed by shredding.

questions.text:
Which of the following should not be incinerated?
  1. Sharps and waste with heavy metals
  2. Reactive chemical waste
  3. Specimens of microorganisms
  4. Pressurized gas containers
  5. Live or attenuated vaccines
questions.solution:
Specimens of microorganisms and live or attenuated vaccines can be incinerated.

Wastes that should not be incinerated are:

  • Sharps
  • Pressurized gas containers
  • Reactive chemical waste
  • Waste with heavy metals like mercury and cadmium
  • PVC
  • Photographic or radiographic waste

questions.text: An orthopedic resident has removed a K-wire from the fractured olecranon of a 13-year-old boy. Where should he discard this?
questions.solution:
Metallic body implants are disposed of in cardboard boxes with blue-colored markings.

The contents of the blue box are sent to Common Biomedical Waste Treatment and Disposal Facility (CBWTF). In the facility, these items are sterilized by autoclaving or microwaving and then sent for recycling.

 

In case of delay in sending the waste to the treatment facility, 2% sodium hypochlorite solution can be used for pre-treatment storage until the contents of the blue bag can be picked up by the CBWTF operator.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man is brought to you following an accident. How would you discard his blood-soaked dressing material?

choices.text: Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
Pour 5% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
Put the dressing material directly in an appropriate bag and send for incineration
Pour 10% non chlorinated chemicals on the dressing material and send for incineration

questions.solution:
The blood-soaked dressing material should be disposed of in a non-chlorinated yellow bag and sent for incineration. Pretreatment is not a requisite for incinerating soiled waste.

Items that require pretreatment with non-chlorinated chemicals before incineration:

  • Used blood bags
  • Other infectious plastic and liquid wastes 
  • Laboratory cultures, stocks, or specimens of microorganisms
  • Live or attenuated vaccines
  • Human and animal cell cultures used in research
  • Dishes, and devices used for cultures

questions.text: Which of the following disposal methods is not as per biomedical waste management guidelines?

choices.text: Disposal of a dead fetus of 21 weeks in a yellow bag  by deep burial in rural areas
Pre-treatment of laboratory cultures with non-chlorinated disinfectant
Disposal of a glass ampoule with its cytotoxic drug through incineration
Disposal of radiological waste by deep burial

questions.solution:
Radiological waste is not considered biomedical waste. Hence, deep burial is not done.

Disposal of radiological is covered under the provisions of the Atomic Energy Act. The radiological effluents are incinerated in a dedicated incinerator having off-gas cleaning facility. Another method is to convert the organic base into an aqueous form by treating it with sodium hydroxide. 

Option A: Dead fetuses under the age of viability are considered human anatomical waste. Anatomical waste can be disposed of by deep burial in rural areas, where a common biomedical treatment facility and incineration is not available.

Option B: Laboratory cultures are classified under the category of microbiology, biotechnology, and other clinical laboratory waste. They are pretreated with a non-chlorinated disinfectant before they are sent for incineration.

Option C: The cytotoxic drugs are disposed of along with their packaging, through incineration.

questions.text: You are asked to catheterize an HBsAg-positive man before hernia surgery.  According to the BMW management rules, where would you dispose of the plastic cover of the catheter?
questions.solution:
The outer plastic cover of the Foleys catheter is discarded in a black bag. 

Foleys catheters are packaged in plastic covers to keep them sterile. The plastic cover is not biomedical waste but is a part of general (municipal) waste. Hence, it is discarded in the black bag. The foleys catheter is disposed of in a red bag.

As per Bio-Medical Waste Management Rules, the general waste must be disposed of in green bins (for recyclable waste) and blue bins (for non-recyclable waste) containing black plastic bags.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases should healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste be vaccinated against?
questions.solution:
Healthcare workers involved in handling biomedical waste should be vaccinated against hepatitis B and tetanus.

These are most likely to be transmitted by the handling of biomedical waste. Yearly health check-ups should be done, and a booster dose should be given if needed.

questions.text: An on-site waste treatment and disposal facility should be built in a hospital if the nearest common biomedical treatment facility is:
questions.solution:
According to biomedical waste management rules of 2016, healthcare establishments shall establish an on-site treatment and disposal facility only when a common biomedical treatment facility (CBMWTF) is more than 75 km away.

According to these rules, biomedical waste (BMW) from healthcare facilities is to be transported to a CMBWTF. The establishment of CBMWTF reduces the need for transport and cost of treatment/ kg of BMW.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a high-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste?
questions.solution:
Microwaving is a low-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste.

The heating systems used for the treatment and disposal of biomedical waste are:

Low-heat system High-heat system

Autoclaving: Uses steam. It is of two types-

  1. Gravity flow autoclave 
  2. Vacuum autoclave

Microwaving: Uses moist heat and steam generated by microwave energy

Incineration: Waste is destroyed/denatured under high temperatures 

Plasma pyrolysis: Waste is treated at high temperatures under controlled conditions to form gases that are subjected to combustion in the secondary chamber

Hydroclaving: The waste is subjected to indirect heating by applying steam to the outer jacket

Dry heat sterilization: Waste sharps are treated using dry heat at a temperature >185 C for 150 minutes

questions.text: Which of the following disposal methods uses high temperature and dry oxidation?
questions.solution:
Incineration is a high-temperature dry oxidation process.

Waste that is incinerated need not undergo any type of pre-treatment. It helps to reduce weight as well as volume. The temperature in the incinerator is 800⁰C in the primary chamber and 1050⁰C in the secondary chamber.

Types of incinerators:

  • Rotary kilns
  • Single chamber pyrolytic
  • Double chamber pyrolytic

The heating systems used for the treatment and disposal of biomedical waste are:

Low-heat system High-heat system

Autoclaving: Uses steam. It is of two types-

  1. Gravity flow autoclave 
  2. Vacuum autoclave

Microwaving: Uses moist heat and steam generated by microwave energy

Incineration: Waste is destroyed/denatured under high temperatures 

Plasma pyrolysis: Waste is treated at high temperatures under controlled conditions to form gases that are subjected to combustion in the secondary chamber

Hydroclaving: The waste is subjected to indirect heating by applying steam to the outer jacket

Dry heat sterilization: Waste sharps are treated using dry heat at a temperature >185 C for 150 minutes

questions.text: In a treatment facility, which of the following cannot be used to verify the treatment of biomedical waste done by incineration?
questions.solution:
Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis is not used to verify thermal methods of biomedical waste disposal. It is a biological larvicide, used in nonpotable water for killing mosquito larvae.

The following can be used to verify the adequacy of thermal methods of biomedical waste disposal:

  • Bacillus atropheus
  • Bacillus subtilis
  • Geobacillus stearothermophilus

questions.text: At a waste treatment facility,  pharmaceutical waste was mixed with cement, lime, and water before disposal. What is this method known as?
questions.solution:
Inertization is the process of mixing biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the toxicity of the waste and to reduce the contamination of groundwater. It is most commonly done for incineration ash with high metal content.

The typical composition of the inertization mixture is:

  • 65% pharmaceutical waste
  • 15% cement
  • 15% lime
  • 5% water

questions.text: What is the correct combination of temperature and duration used in a hot air oven?
questions.solution:
The correct combinations of temperature and duration of sterilisation in a hot air oven is:

  • 180°C for 30 mins
  • 170°C for 60 mins
  • 160⁰C for 2 hours

It can be used to sterilize powders, glasswares, and oils.

An autoclave is another apparatus that is used for sterilization. It uses steam at a temperature of 121⁰C for 30 mins under 15 lbs of pressure.

questions.text: All the following are the characteristics of waste that can be incinerated except:
questions.solution:
Only waste material containing <5% of noncombustible solids can be incinerated. Wastes that are incinerated go in the yellow bag.

Waste products with the following characteristics can be incinerated:

  • Combustible matter >60%
  • Non-combustible solid <5%
  • Non-combustible fine <20%
  • Low heating volume
  • Moisture content <30%.

questions.text: You are working in a covid ward. After doffing, where will you dispose of the plastic coverall?
questions.solution:
The plastic coverall used by a healthcare worker during the COVID-19 pandemic should be disposed of in the red bin.

Related Pearl: Biomedical Waste (BMW) Management -COVID 19

In addition to the current BMW Management rules, the following measures are proposed

  • To report opening/operation of COVID 19 Ward/ICU/Lab/Collection Centre to SPCB (State Pollution Control Board) and CBWTF (Common Biomedical Waste Treatment Facility) in that area
  • Dedicated sanitation workers deputed only to collect COVID 19 BMW
  • It is mandatory for all BMW bags and containers from COVID 19 areas to carry "COVID 19 WASTE" label
  • Keep separate colour coded bins with foot operated lids
  • The inner and outer surfaces of these containers must be disinfected daily with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution
  • To ensure no leaks, double layers (2 bags) are used
